definitions: having been closed or fastened to prevent access or passage
not currently open for business or not functioning normally
examples: The shut door blocked all sounds from outside
Keep your eyes shut during the surprise preparation
The factory remained shut throughout the holiday season
Most stores are shut on Sunday evenings here

definitions: having window shutters that are closed to block light or view
describing a business or building that has been permanently closed down
examples: The shuttered windows gave the house a deserted appearance
We stayed in a shuttered room during the storm
The shuttered factory stood as a monument to economic decline
Many shuttered restaurants never reopened after the crisis

definitions: feeling nervous or timid in social situations, especially with unfamiliar people
falling short of a specified amount or number by a small margin
examples: The shy child hid behind her mother's legs
He's too shy to speak in public meetings
We're still three votes shy of a majority
The project came up shy of its funding goal

definitions: affected by physical illness or disease; not in good health
feeling strong disgust or moral revulsion about something unpleasant
showing mental disturbance or having morbid or perverted interests
examples: The sick patient needed immediate medical attention
She felt too sick to go to work today
I'm sick of hearing the same excuses repeatedly
The corrupt politician's actions made everyone sick
His sick jokes about tragedy upset many people
The killer had a sick fascination with violence

definitions: causing a feeling of nausea or physical disgust through smell, sight, or motion
causing strong moral disgust or outrage; deeply offensive to one's sense of right
examples: The sickening smell of rotting garbage filled the alley
The boat's sickening motion made passengers queasy
The sickening display of cruelty shocked the witnesses
It's sickening how much food gets wasted daily

definitions: frequently suffering from illness or having weak health constitution
having an unhealthy appearance suggesting illness or poor condition
unpleasantly excessive in sweetness or sentimentality to the point of nausea
examples: The sickly child missed many days of school
She had been sickly since early childhood
His sickly pale complexion worried his mother
The sickly yellow light made everyone look ill
The cake had a sickly sweet frosting nobody enjoyed
Her sickly sweet voice grated on everyone's nerves

definitions: positioned at or relating to the side of something rather than front or back
subsidiary to the main thing; additional but less important than primary
examples: The side entrance provides wheelchair access to the building
She parked in the side street to avoid traffic
His side business selling crafts supplements his main income
The medication may cause drowsiness as a side effect

definitions: describing a throwing motion where the arm moves horizontally at shoulder level
examples: His sidearm pitching style confused many batters
The quarterback made a sidearm pass to avoid defenders

definitions: moving, facing, or positioned toward one side rather than forward or backward
indirect or evasive rather than straightforward in manner or approach
examples: The crab made its sideways shuffle across the sand
She gave him a sideways glance of disapproval
His sideways criticism of the policy annoyed his colleagues
She took a sideways approach to the sensitive topic

definitions: having the ability to see; not blind or visually impaired
having been seen or observed, especially something rare or noteworthy
examples: The sighted guide helped the blind students navigate campus
Most sighted people take their vision for granted
The rarely sighted bird attracted dozens of photographers
Several sighted UFO reports came from that area

definitions: relating to or involving signs, especially in sign language communication
examples: She teaches sign language at the community college
The sign interpreter stood beside the speaker

definitions: remarkably important, notable, or distinguished; standing out as particularly significant
examples: Her signal achievement was winning three gold medals
The treaty marked a signal moment in history

definitions: having a signature affixed as authentication or authorization
communicated or expressed using sign language rather than spoken words
examples: The signed contract became legally binding immediately
She treasured her signed copy of the book
The signed performance made the play accessible to all
They provided signed interpretation for deaf attendees

definitions: sufficiently important to be worthy of attention; having considerable meaning or consequence
large enough to be meaningful in statistical analysis; not likely due to chance
examples: The discovery represents a significant breakthrough in cancer research
She made significant contributions to the project's success
The study found statistically significant differences between groups
There was no significant correlation between the variables

definitions: made quiet or unable to speak through force, intimidation, or other means
examples: The silenced critics dared not speak against the regime
The silenced gun made only a soft whisper

definitions: completely quiet, producing no sound or noise whatsoever
refraining from speech; choosing not to speak or communicate verbally
written but not pronounced when the word is spoken aloud
examples: The library remained silent during study hours
Silent films relied on visual storytelling techniques
She remained silent throughout the entire interrogation
His silent disapproval was obvious to everyone
The 'k' in 'knife' is a silent letter
Many English words contain silent consonants

definitions: made from silk fabric or containing silk fibers
having the smooth, soft, lustrous quality characteristic of silk
examples: She wore silken scarves from her travels abroad
The silken sheets felt luxurious against her skin
Her silken voice charmed everyone at the party
The cat's silken fur gleamed in the sunlight

definitions: having a smooth, soft, fine texture resembling that of silk
smoothly confident and sophisticated in manner, sometimes excessively so
examples: The shampoo left her hair feeling silky smooth
The puppy's silky ears were irresistibly soft
His silky manner made some people distrust him
The salesman's silky voice promised too much

definitions: showing a lack of common sense or good judgment; foolish
playfully lighthearted and amusing in a childlike or harmless way
examples: Making that investment was a silly financial decision
Don't be silly; of course you're invited
The children made silly faces at each other
We spent the evening telling silly jokes

definitions: containing or covered with silt, fine sedimentary material deposited by water
examples: The silty river water was unsuitable for drinking
Silty soil can be very fertile for agriculture

definitions: made from or containing the precious metal silver
having a shiny gray-white color resembling the metal silver
marking or celebrating a twenty-fifth anniversary, especially of marriage
examples: She inherited her grandmother's silver jewelry collection
The silver coins were worth more than face value
His silver hair made him look distinguished
The car's silver paint gleamed in the sunlight
They celebrated their silver wedding anniversary in Paris
The company's silver jubilee included special promotions

definitions: having a bright shiny gray-white appearance like polished silver
having a clear, light, ringing quality like a silver bell
examples: The fish's silvery scales glinted beneath the water
Silvery moonlight illuminated the garden path
Her silvery laugh echoed through the empty hall
The wind chimes made a silvery sound

definitions: relating to or resembling apes or monkeys in appearance or behavior
examples: His simian features included prominent brows and long arms
The actor's simian movements perfectly captured the character

definitions: having characteristics in common; alike in appearance, nature, or qualities but not identical
examples: The twins wore similar outfits to the party
These two problems require similar solutions

definitions: easy to understand, do, or use; not complex or complicated
plain and basic without decoration or unnecessary additions; unadorned
modest and unpretentious in lifestyle or bearing; unsophisticated
examples: The solution was surprisingly simple once explained
She preferred simple recipes with few ingredients
They lived in a simple cottage by the sea
Her simple dress was elegant in its restraint
Despite his wealth, he maintained simple tastes
The monks led simple lives of prayer

definitions: treating complex issues as if they were much simpler than they really are
examples: His simplistic analysis ignored crucial economic factors
The movie offered a simplistic view of history

definitions: created artificially to imitate or reproduce the appearance or characteristics of something real
examples: The pilots trained in simulated flight conditions
She wore a necklace with simulated pearls

definitions: happening, existing, or done at exactly the same time as something else
examples: The simultaneous explosions suggested coordinated planning
She managed simultaneous careers in music and acting

definitions: free from pretense or deceit; genuinely feeling or expressing what one says
examples: Her sincere apology helped repair their friendship
He gave sincere thanks for all their help

definitions: contrary to religious or moral law; wicked or immoral
shockingly excessive or unreasonable, especially regarding waste or indulgence
examples: The priest warned against sinful thoughts and deeds
Many considered gambling a sinful activity
It's sinful to waste so much food
The dessert was sinfully delicious but terribly unhealthy

definitions: producing musical sounds with the voice in melody
making a high-pitched whistling or humming sound like certain objects
examples: The singing birds welcomed the dawn
A singing telegram arrived for her birthday
The singing kettle announced the water was ready
She could hear the singing wires in the wind

definitions: consisting of or amounting to only one; not multiple
not married or not in a committed romantic relationship
designed for or used by one person rather than shared
examples: Not a single person showed up for the meeting
She won by a single point
He remained single throughout his thirties
The single employees often socialized after work
I booked a single room for my stay
Single tickets cost more than returns

definitions: denoting or referring to just one person or thing in grammar
remarkably unusual or extraordinary; standing out from others
examples: 'Cat' is a singular noun requiring singular verbs
The singular form differs from the plural
She showed singular dedication to her research
It was a singular honor to meet the president

definitions: giving the impression that something harmful or evil is happening or will happen
examples: The sinister figure lurked in the shadows
There was something sinister about his smile

definitions: having many curves and turns; moving in a graceful winding way
examples: The sinuous river wound through the valley
The dancer's sinuous movements captivated the audience

definitions: showing characteristics considered unmanly; weak, cowardly, or excessively delicate
examples: The bullies called him sissy for avoiding fights
She rejected sissy colors for her son's room

definitions: currently holding an office or position, especially in government
currently in session or meeting formally for business
examples: The sitting president faced a tough reelection campaign
All sitting members must vote on this issue
Parliament cannot pass new laws when not sitting
The sitting court will hear arguments tomorrow

definitions: located in a particular place or position, especially in relation to surroundings
examples: The hotel is situated near the beach
Their office is ideally situated downtown

definitions: amounting to the number that is one more than five
examples: She has six children attending different schools
The meeting is scheduled for six o'clock

definitions: amounting to the number that is six plus ten
examples: She celebrated her sixteenth birthday with friends
The building has sixteen floors including the basement

definitions: coming after the fifteenth in position, time, or order in a sequence
examples: The sixteenth century saw major religious reforms
She finished in sixteenth place

definitions: coming after the fifth in position, time, or order in a sequence
examples: She's in sixth grade this year
The team finished in sixth place

definitions: coming after the fifty-ninth in position, time, or order in a sequence
examples: They celebrated their sixtieth wedding anniversary together
It was his sixtieth birthday party

definitions: amounting to the number that is six times ten
examples: The speed limit here is sixty miles per hour
She retired at sixty years old

definitions: fairly large in size, number, or amount; considerable or substantial
examples: They made a sizable donation to the charity
A sizable crowd gathered for the announcement

definitions: having or made to a particular or specified dimension or measurement
examples: They only sell one size fits all gloves
These are standard size sheets for this bed

definitions: fairly large in size, number, or amount; considerable or substantial
examples: The company owns a sizeable portion of the market
There's a sizeable difference in their salaries

definitions: having a particular or specified size, especially as indicated by adjective
examples: The medium sized dog fit perfectly in the carrier
They ordered different sized pizzas for the party

definitions: relating to or forming the skeleton of the body
extremely thin, with bones clearly visible through the skin
reduced to the basic framework or minimum essential elements
examples: The skeletal system provides structural support for the body
Archaeologists discovered skeletal remains in the tomb
The skeletal prisoners shocked the liberating soldiers
Her skeletal appearance worried her family
They operated with skeletal staff during the holiday
Only a skeletal outline of the plan exists

definitions: not easily convinced; having doubts or reservations about something's truth or value
examples: Scientists remained skeptical of the extraordinary claims
She was skeptical about his sudden change
